natural problem: Let $p(x)$ be defined on $2 \le x \le 10$ such that $$p(x) = \begin{cases} x + 1 &\quad \lfloor x \rfloor\text{ is prime} \\ p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) &\quad \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of $\lfloor x\rfloor.$ Express the range of $p$ in interval notation.
natural solution: By definition of $p$, for any prime number $x$ such that $2 \le x \le 10$, then $[x+1,x+2) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$. It follows that $[3,4) \cup [4,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$.

Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$. Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.
Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 10"
and h1 : "p x = (if is_prime(floor x) then x + 1 else p (primefactors (floor x) ! (length (primefactors (floor x)) - 1)) + (x + 1 - floor x))"
shows  "3 \<le> p x \<and> p x < 7 \<or> 8 \<le> p x \<and> p x < 9"

The final Answer is [3,7] \cup [8,9)
 ### Proof
 By definition of $p$, for any prime number $x$ such that $2 \le x \le 10$, then $[x+1,x+2) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$. It follows that $[3,4) \cup [4,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$.
 Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$.  Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.

theorem
fixes x y :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 10"
and h1 : "p x = (if is_prime(floor x) then x + 1 else p (primefactors (floor x) ! (length (primefactors (floor x)) - 1)) + (x + 1 - floor x))"

a_0.informal problem: Consider a real number $x$ between 2 and 10, inclusive. Let's define a function $p(x)$ as follows: if the floor of $x$ is a prime number, then $p(x) = x + 1$. Otherwise, $p(x)$ is defined as the last prime factor of the floor of $x$ plus the fractional part of $x$ plus 1. Determine the possible values of $p(x)$. The final answer is that $p(x)$ is either between 3 and 7 (exclusive) or between 8 and 9 (exclusive).

a_1.formal problem: Sorry, but the problem you're asking to translate is too complex for a direct translation into Isabelle/HOL. The concept of a function being defined in terms of itself (recursion) can be expressed in Isabelle/HOL, but the notion of the "greatest prime factor" is nontrivial to express in this language. Furthermore, expressing the concept of a function that is defined differently on different domains (piecewise-defined functions) is also nontrivial in Isabelle/HOL. So, a direct translation of this problem is not possible in this case.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> ((is_prime (floor x) \<longrightarrow> p x = x + 1) \<and> (\<not> is_prime (floor x) \<longrightarrow> p x = p y + (x + 1 - floor x)))"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 10 \<and> \<not> is_prime (floor x) \<longrightarrow> y = greatest_prime_factor (floor x)"
shows  "range p = {3..7} \<union> {8..<9}"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $p(x)$ be defined on $2 \le x \le 10$ such that $$p(x) = \begin{cases} x + 1 &\quad \lfloor x \rfloor\text{ is prime} \\ p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) &\quad \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of $\lfloor x\rfloor.$ Express the range of $p$ in interval notation. The final Answer is [3,7] \cup [8,9)
 ### Proof
 By definition of $p$, for any prime number $x$ such that $2 \le x \le 10$, then $[x+1,x+2) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$. It follows that $[3,4) \cup [4,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$.
 Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$. Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.
 Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.
 *)

a_2.informal problem: Define a function $p(x)$ on the interval $[2,10]$ as follows: if the integer part of $x$ is prime, then $p(x) = x + 1$. Otherwise, $p(x) = p(y) + (x + 1 - \text{floor}(x))$, where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of the integer part of $x$. Find the range of $p(x)$. The range of $p(x)$ is the union of the interval from 3 to 7, inclusive, and the interval from 8 to 9, exclusive.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. (floor x \<in> prime) \<longrightarrow> p x = x + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. (floor x \<notin> prime) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>y. y = greatest_prime_factor (floor x) \<and> p x = p y + (x + 1 - floor x))"
shows  "((\<exists>z. p z = z + 1 \<and> 3 \<le> z \<and> z \<le> 7) \<or> (\<exists>z. p z = z + 1 \<and> 8 \<le> z \<and> z < 9))"

The final Answer is [3,7] \cup [8,9)
 ### Proof
 By definition of $p$, for any prime number $x$ such that $2 \le x \le 10$, then $[x+1,x+2) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$. It follows that $[3,4) \cup [4,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$.
 Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$. Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.
 Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.
 *)

a_4.informal problem:
Consider a function $p(x)$ defined as follows:

1. If the floor of $x$ is prime, then $p(x) = x + 1$.
2. If the floor of $x$ is not prime, then $p(x) = p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor)$, where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of the floor of $x$.

Given that $2 \leq x \leq 10$, find if there exists a value of $z$ in two intervals, $3 \leq z \leq 7$ and $8 \leq z < 9$, such that $p(z) = z + 1$.

theorem
fixes x y p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x"

shows  "p x \<in> {3..7} \<union> {8..<9}"

(* ### Problem

Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.
 Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.
 *)

a_5.informal problem:
Define a function $p(x)$ as follows:
- If $x$ is an integer and a prime number, then $p(x) = x + 1$.
- If $x$ is not an integer prime number, then there exists a number $y$ such that $y$ is the greatest prime factor of $\lfloor x \rfloor$ and $p(x) = p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor)$.

Given that $2 \leq x \leq 10$, determine the range of possible values for $p(x)$. The final answer is $p(x) \in [3, 7] \cup [8, 9)$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 10"
and h2 : "f x = (\<forall>n \<in> {2..<x}. x mod n \<noteq> 0)"
and h3 : "\<And>x. f x \<Longrightarrow> p x = x + 1"
and h4 : "\<And>x. \<not> f x \<Longrightarrow> p x = p y + (x + 1 - floor x) where y is the greatest prime factor of floor x"
shows  "3 \<le> p x \<and> p x \<le> 7 \<or> 8 \<le> p x \<and> p x < 9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $p(x)$ be defined on $2 \le x \le 10$ such that $$p(x) = \begin{cases} x + 1 &\quad \lfloor x \rfloor\text{ is prime} \\ p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) &\quad \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of $\lfloor x\rfloor.$ Express the range of $p$ in interval notation. The final Answer is [3,7] \cup [8,9)
 ### Proof
 By definition of $p$, for any prime number $x$ such that $2 \le x \le 10$, then $[x+1,x+2) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$. It follows that $[3,4) \cup [4,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$.
 Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$. Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.
 Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.
 *)

Let $f(x)$ be a function that determines if a number is prime, such that $f(x) = True$ if $x$ is a prime number and $f(x) = False$ otherwise. Let $p(x)$ be a function defined as follows:

1. If $x$ is prime, then $p(x) = x + 1$.
2. If $x$ is not prime, then $p(x) = p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor)$, where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of $\lfloor x \rfloor$.

Given that $2 \leq x \leq 10$, find the range of possible values for $p(x)$. The final answer is $3 \leq p(x) \leq 7$ or $8 \leq p(x) < 9$.

 Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$. Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 10"
and h2 : "(\<lfloor>x\<rfloor> prime \<longrightarrow> p x = x + 1) \<and> (\<not> (\<lfloor>x\<rfloor> prime) \<longrightarrow> p x = p y + (x + 1 - \<lfloor>x\<rfloor>))"
shows  "p x \<in> {3..7} \<union> {8..<9}"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $p(x)$ be defined on $2 \le x \le 10$ such that $$p(x) = \begin{cases} x + 1 &\quad \lfloor x \rfloor\text{ is prime} \\ p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) &\quad \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ where $y$ is the greatest prime factor of $\lfloor x\rfloor.$ Express the range of $p$ in interval notation. The final Answer is [3,7] \cup [8,9)
 ### Proof
 By definition of $p$, for any prime number $x$ such that $2 \le x \le 10$, then $[x+1,x+2) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$. It follows that $[3,4) \cup [4,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$.
 Since the largest prime factor of a composite number less than or equal to $10$ is $5$, then the largest possible value of $p$ on a composite number is $p(10) = p(5)+1 = 7$. Also, we notice that $[5,6) \subset \text{range}\,(p)$, since for any $x \in [6,7)$, then $p(x) = p(3) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor) = 5 + x - \lfloor x \rfloor$.
 Combining all of this, it follows that the range of $p$ is equal to $[3,5) \cup [6,7) \cup [8,9) \cup \{7\} \cup [5,6) = \boxed{[3,7] \cup [8,9)}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "2 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 10"
and h2 : "(\<lfloor>x\<rfloor> prime \<longrightarrow> p x = x + 1) \<and> (\<not> (\<lfloor>x\<rfloor> prime) \<longrightarrow> p x = p y + (x + 1 - \<lfloor>x\<rfloor>))"
shows  "p x \<in> {3..7} \<union> {8..<9}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Define a function $p(x)$ that depends on $x$ and $y$ as follows: if the largest integer less than or equal to $x$ (denoted as $\lfloor x \rfloor$) is prime, then $p(x) = x + 1$. Otherwise, $p(x) = p(y) + (x + 1 - \lfloor x \rfloor)$. Given that $2 \leq x \leq 10$, find the range of possible values for $p(x)$. The final answer is that $p(x)$ lies in the interval $[3, 7]$ or the half-open interval $[8, 9)$.
